content: Federal student loan forgiveness and repayment programs have been in existence since the National Defense Education Act of 1958. These programs offer borrowers the opportunity to have their student loan debt forgiven or repaid in exchange for service in specific professions or occupations. Currently, there are over 50 federal loan forgiveness and repayment programs available. Loan forgiveness and repayment programs have been created, with over 50 authorized and approximately 30 operational as of October 1, 2017. These programs involve the federal government forgiving or canceling a portion of an individual's student loan debt in exchange for fulfilling certain requirements, often through public service or specific occupations. Some programs also offer loan forgiveness as part of income-driven repayment plans. Loan forgiveness and repayment programs aim to provide financial incentives for individuals to enter public service or high-need professions, occupations, or specialties. They also offer debt relief to borrowers who have not fully repaid their student loans after an extended period of time. These benefits are available to borrowers of federal student loans who choose to enter public service, work in specific professions, or repay their loans through an income-driven repayment plan. Other forms of debt relief may be available to borrowers in specific circumstances, such as loan discharge for disability, death, school closure, false certification, unauthorized loans, unpaid refunds, successful defense to repayment, and bankruptcy. The NDSL program, established in 1958, was one of the earliest federal student loan forgiveness programs. In response to the Soviet Union's Sputnik launch in 1957, Congress funded education programs like the NDSL program, offering low-interest loans to college students. A student loan forgiveness component was also included to attract more teachers by canceling up to half of their loans for full-time public school teaching. The NDSL loan forgiveness program was initially created to offer low-interest loans to college students in response to the Soviet Union's Sputnik launch in 1957. It later evolved to provide loan forgiveness benefits to teachers in elementary or secondary schools with low-income students or students with disabilities, as well as those serving in Head Start programs or in the Armed Forces. Borrowers could have a portion of their loans canceled based on years of public service completed. The Federal Perkins Loan Program, formerly known as the NDSL, was established in response to the Soviet Union's Sputnik launch in 1957. It later expanded to include loan forgiveness programs for teachers, healthcare professionals, and other high-need areas. The repayments are included in gross income for tax purposes, and the program is funded through discretionary appropriations. Annual data on beneficiaries and repayments are currently unavailable. The Coast Guard Education Loan Repayment Program, authorized by the Coast Guard and Maritime Transportation Act of 2004, aims to recruit and retain qualified enlisted members in specialty occupations. Eligible loans include FFEL, Direct Loans, PLUS Loans, and Perkins loans. To qualify for repayment benefits, borrowers must serve in active duty in determined specialty occupations, with payments based on each complete year of service. The maximum benefit allowed is the greater of 33 1/3% of the outstanding student loan or $1,500 per year. No post-award conditions or federal tax treatment restrictions are specified. Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act Loan Repayment Program Authority under the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, FDA, recruits health professionals for research. Eligible loans cover tuition and living expenses. No specific details on annual amounts, beneficiaries, or CRS reports are available. The Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act Loan Repayment Program offers private loans for tuition, educational expenses, and living expenses for health professionals conducting research while FDA employees. Borrowers must complete at least three years of service to receive up to $20,000 per year. Eligibility requires a substantial amount of education loans relative to income. Post-award conditions include repayment of loan amounts if service is not completed. The National Indian Forest Resources Management Postgraduation Recruitment Assumption of Student Loans Authority program, administered by the Department of the Interior, Bureau of Indian Affairs, aims to recruit Indian and Alaska Native individuals by offering student loan repayment assistance. The program allows for loan repayments to be excluded from gross income under certain conditions. Annual amounts discharged or repaid were $2.2 million in FY2013, with 248 beneficiaries that year. No CRS reports or additional resources are available for FY2014-FY2017. The National Indian Forest Resources Management Postgraduation Recruitment Assumption of Student Loans Authority program, administered by the Department of the Interior, Bureau of Indian Affairs, recruits Indian and Alaska Native graduate foresters and forestry technicians by offering student loan repayment assistance. Eligible loans include various types from established lending institutions. Borrowers must be Indian or Alaska Native professional foresters or forester technicians who have completed a forestry-related curriculum at an accredited institution and enter into a service agreement with a BIA or tribal forestry program. Repayment benefits are based on each complete year of service, with a maximum benefit of $5,000 per year. The American Indian Agricultural Resource Management Postgraduation Recruitment Assumption of Student Loans Authority program offers up to $5,000 per year in student loan repayment assistance. Borrowers must repay the loans assumed by the agency if they fail to complete their service, with the amount adjusted based on the obligated service performed. Federal tax treatment includes the repayments in gross income. Budgetary classification is discretionary, with no information available on previous amounts appropriated, annual amount discharged or repaid, or the number of beneficiaries. No CRS reports or additional resources are available. The American Indian Agricultural Resource Management Postgraduation Recruitment Assumption of Student Loans Authority program, under Title II, §202; 25 U.S.C. §3732, administered by the Department of the Interior, Bureau of Indian Affairs, aims to recruit Indian and Alaska Natives for employment as natural resource and agriculture technicians. Eligible loans include any outstanding student loan from established lending institutions. Borrowers must be Indian or Alaska Native technicians who have completed a related curriculum and entered into a service agreement with a BIA or tribal agriculture program to qualify for repayment benefits.
